channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: European Union Suspends Talks With Ukraine Over Trade Deal
item.description: A top European Union official all but accused Ukraine’s president, Viktor F. Yanukovich, of dissembling over the trade deal that protesters have been demanding for weeks.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: A sprawling crowd packed Independence Square in Kiev on Sunday to hear several speeches, including one by Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona.

item.title: Thousands Gather to Bury Mandela in His Home Village
item.description: Nelson Mandela’s funeral began with speeches, choirs and television cameras in a cavernous dome housing thousands, and it ended almost six hours later with a simpler moment at his family burial site.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN, JOHN ELIGON and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Nelson Mandela’s flag-covered coffin at the burial site in Qunu, South Africa.

item.title: Signs of Momentum Shifting to Protesters in Ukraine
item.description: After weeks in which President Viktor F. Yanukovich appeared to have the upper hand, there were signs that the president was no longer so sure of himself.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Riot police officers stood guard on Saturday at a rally supporting the government as protesters against it stood behind a fence.

item.title: Kim Jong-un’s Aunt Appears to Survive Husband’s Purge
item.description: Kim Kyong-hui was named on a leadership list in North Korea’s state-run media, signaling she may have avoided the fate of her husband, who was executed last week.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Following the Murky Trail Left by Diamonds and Cash
item.description: A flurry of legal cases, investigations and leaked bank documents have drawn attention to the opaque movement of diamond-backed money.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:credit: Jasper Juinen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A square mile of traders in Antwerp, Belgium, forms the hub of the global diamond industry.

item.title: Far Right in Eastern Europe Makes Gains as Syrians Arrive
item.description: A party known as Ataka, which means attack, champions “Bulgaria for Bulgarians” and has denounced Syrian refugees as terrorists whom Bulgaria, the European Union’s poorest nation, must expel.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Members of Bulgarian nationalist groups patrolled Sofia, Bulgaria’s capital, last month, an example of “civil patrols” by nationalists in immigrant regions.

item.title: Ciudad Juárez, a Border City Known for Killing, Gets Back to Living
item.description: Only a few years ago, Ciudad Juárez was a symbol of drug war devastation. But the killing has subsided, replaced by new businesses, returning residents and cautious hope.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Iran Reports Successfully Sending Another Monkey Into Space
item.description: Iran’s state television said the country used liquid fuel for the first time to launch the rocket, named Pajohesh, meaning “research” in Farsi.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: At Least Four Are Killed in Kenya Van Explosion
item.description: At least four people were killed in Nairobi after a homemade bomb exploded inside a passenger van.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Egypt to Vote Next Month on New Constitution
item.description: It will be the first gauge of support for the military’s ouster of Egypt’s first fairly elected president, Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Gay South Africans Worry Now That Mandela Is Gone
item.description: On a continent where gay rights are rarely granted, South Africans are concerned that the protections provided by the Constitution may be threatened.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By MARCUS MABRY

item.title: Japan’s Top Voice: High, Polite and on the Phone
item.description: The annual All-Japan Phone-Answering Competition for office workers is a closely watched contest that some say reiterates the stereotype of women in clerical positions.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:credit: Kentaro Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mika Otani, who competed in a telephone-answering contest, said modern women did not want to sound cartoonish.

item.title: The Lede: American Who Killed for Iran’s Revolution in 1980 Resurfaces in C.I.A. Spy Drama
item.description: The C.I.A. contractor who disappeared during a 2007 trip to Iran had traveled there to meet with a man whose life story could provide Hollywood screenwriters with material for a sequel to “Argo.”
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Vocations: The Court Interpreter: Speaking Their Language
item.description: Farah Elahi once practiced law in Pakistan. Now she lives in Wisconsin, using her language skills as an interpreter in the state court system.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICIA R. OLSEN
item.media:credit: Darren Hauck for The New York Times
item.media:description: Farah Elahi speaks Punjabi, Urdu and Hindi.

item.title: United Nations Says Several Peacekeepers Are Killed in Mali
item.description: A bombing killed at least two U.N. peacekeepers in Mali and seriously wounded several others in the troubled northern city of Kidal, U.N. officials said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Mandela’s Body Arrives in Home Province for Funeral Amid Cheers and Songs
item.description: The body of Nelson Mandela was flown by military plane to his native Eastern Cape Province ahead of a state funeral and burial in Qunu, the village where he grew up, on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN

item.title: Cook Islands, a Paradise of Untouchable Assets
item.description: These flyspeck islands in the Pacific have the reputation of being a place where assets can be hidden from business partners, litigants or former spouses.
item.dc:creator: By LESLIE WAYNE

item.title: Samsung: Uneasy in the Lead
item.description: While the Korean industrial group dominates some electronics categories, its chairman, Lee Kun-hee, warns employees against complacency.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC PFANNER and BRIAN X. CHEN
item.media:description: Lee Kun-hee, third from left, chairman of Samsung, who transformed a second-rate maker of household appliances into today’s hugely successful conglomerate.

item.title: Social Democrats Secure a Third Term for Merkel
item.description: Germany’s center-left Social Democrats have voted heavily in favor of a new coalition with Chancellor Angela Merkel, paving the way for her to be sworn in for a third term on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Sigmar Gabriel, chairman of Germany's Social Democratic Party, speaks in Berlin on Saturday. Mr. Gabriel is likely to become vice chancellor under Angela Merkel, who is set to be sworn in for a third term as chancellor on Tuesday.

item.title: Pakistan’s Chief Justice Leaves a Mixed Legacy
item.description: As Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry steps down as chief justice this week, his fight against Pakistan’s military rulers looms large in his legacy — as does his failure to reform a weak legal system.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of suspected criminals on their way to court in Islamabad.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Recalling the Other Heroes of the Anti-Apartheid Struggle
item.description: The days of celebration of Nelson Mandela’s life and the grief at his death tempted some to limit the accolades to him while forgetting the contributions of others.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oliver Tambo, center, African National Congress president with Nelson Mandela and Winnie Mandela in December 1990.

item.title: France Broadens Its Surveillance Power
item.description: The legislature approved an electronic surveillance law that critics feared would markedly expand electronic surveillance of French residents and businesses.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: Officials Say U.S. May Never Know Extent of Snowden’s Leaks
item.description: Investigators remain in the dark partly because the facility where the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden worked was not equipped with software to monitor employees.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: Calls Mount to Free 2 Iranian Opposition Leaders
item.description: The calls for the men’s release are posing a major domestic test for President Hassan Rouhani, who must placate his reformist supporters without antagonizing hard-liners.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mir Hussein Moussavi in 2009, when he was a presidential candidate. He is under house arrest.

item.title: As Rover Lands, China Joins Moon Club
item.description: China became the third country to accomplish a “soft landing,” in which a rover will explore the lunar surface to further the nation’s broader ambitions in space.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:credit: Cctv, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Chinese television broadcast images of the rover after it landed on the moon. China is the third country to reach the moon.
